newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - June 10.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - June 10.

text.p: Maori protesters given ultimatum: Ruapehu District Council said on Monday night that it would give Maori protesters occupying a Waiouru park 24 hours to leave. Page 1.

Ministers refuse to visit Waiouru land protesters: Conservation Minister Nick Smith and Treaty Negotiations Minister Doug Graham have dismissed the Waiouru Maori land occupation as a nuisance and a waste of time. Page 2.
Radio boss calls it a day: Radio Network boss Joan Withers is calling it a day after a meteoric rise to the executive echelons of the media. Page 11.

Montana outlines export plans: Corporate Investments subsidiary Montana Wines expects to almost double exports to one million cases a year by early next decade, according to Montana managing director Peter Hubscher. Page 11.

Emco activity under review: Wholesale power market operator Emco was keen to use its market design and governance skills in other markets but its prime focus would remain the electricity industry, chief executive Lincoln Gould said on Monday. Page 11.

Brierley keeps quiet on Fairfax stake: Brierley Investments had no comment on Monday on whether it was the eventual buyer of a 2.99 percent stake in Australian publisher John Fairfax Holdings sold by Westpac Banking Corporation on Friday. Page 12.

Loose lips lead police to 1989 death scene: Two men lugged a body from a car boot into the garage of a West Auckland house as they tried to conceal a killing -- and for eight years their cover-up job worked.

Smith optimistic on free trade deal: The Minister for Trade, Lockwood Smith, is confident the Clinton administration will gain the necessary authority to be in a position to negotiate a free trade agreement with New Zealand.
Power joint venture detailed: Newmarket-based Mercury Energy and Utilicorp of the United States have confirmed plans to reduce duplication in the Auckland electricity market.

Red Cross drops gambling game: New Zealand Red Cross on Monday pulled the plug on a direct computer link with an Internet Lotto site after doubts were raised about the legality of such gambling. Page 1.
MMP 'starting to work': Constant public turmoil involving New Zealand First MP Tuku Morgan is hiding the fact that MMP is starting to work within Parliament, says ACT perk-buster Rodney Hide. Page 7.
Cry TV in liquidation as IRD opposes plan: Cry TV has been placed in liquidation after the failure of a complicated plan to keep it afloat. Page 35.
JBL receiver seeking final unpaid creditors: The last rites are being given to the JBL group of companies -- 25 years after they were put in receivership. Page 35.

Extra-big ovens add flavour for Kiwi cooks: New Zealanders demand bigger ovens than overseas consumers, Email has found. It manufactures Simpson and Westinghouse cooking appliances in Christchurch. Page 35.
